value.title: DAX Fridays! #17: DATEDIFF
value.excerpt: In today's video, I will show you how to calculate the difference between two dates using DATEDIFF. I also show you how to overcome the issue when the start date is larger than the end date.  PREVIOUS VIDEO: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-ykkaAtlCMc NEXT VIDEO: -  Link to demo file: http://gofile.me/2kEOD/G4FzzQLvV

value.title: DAX Fridays! #172: LEFT, RIGHT, LEN, SEARCH - Split text by character in DAX
value.excerpt: In today's video, I will show you how to split text by a character using DAX and why this search error happens and how to solve it: The search Text provided to function 'SEARCH' could not be found in the given text.  Here you can download all the pbix files: https://curbal.com/donwload-center  SUBSCRIBE

value.title: DAX Fridays! #18: YTD,QTD, MTD
value.excerpt: Let's go through Year to date, Quater to date and Month to date functions available in DAX!  Keynotes: 00:26 TOTALYTD function in DAX 07:18 TOTALMTD function in DAX 11:22 TOTALQTD function in DAX  Link to Power BI file: https://curbal.com/blog/glossary/totalytd-dax   NEXT VIDEO:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-ykkaAtlCMc

value.title: DAX Fridays! #180: Find text in columns using DAX
value.excerpt: There are a lot of functions that allow you to search for text in a column using DAX and I have already shown you a few, but here is one more! value.title: DAX Fridays! #181: Can't covert text into dates using DAX? Here is why...
value.excerpt: You should use power query to convert text into dates in power bi, but if you have a direct query or live connection and you need to do it in DAX, here is a tutorial of what works, what doesnt and what to watch for.  Enjoy!  Here you can download all the pbix files: https://curbal.com/donwload-center

value.title: DAX Fridays! #182: Why your  Power BI tables sometimes filter, sometimes dont
value.excerpt: Why sometimes your tables filter each other and sometimes they dont?  As a beginner, this confused me deeply, so I hope this video will clarify this for you so you dont have to wonder anymore!  Understanding relationships: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-4ybWQSRcOY  Modeling playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLDz00l_jz6zyfWLZIu8psvTESmKuVDUoG

value.title: DAX Fridays! #183: How to deal with multiple dates in Power BI
value.excerpt: So you have order date, shipped date, required date....and only one calendar. How do you manage that in power bi and DAX?  This scenario is often called role playing dimensions and in this video I will show you two ways to solve it. :) Happy Friday!!  Links to videos mentioned: Introduction to data modeling:

value.title: DAX Fridays! #184: Show last label only on a line chart in Power BI
value.excerpt: Displaying only the last label on a line chart is quite a common scenario that is not supported in Power BI by default, so in today's vide I am going to show you how to do that with a little bit of DAX magic! value.title: DAX Fridays! #21: USERELATIONSHIP
value.excerpt: A common example in a Power BI table is to have multiple dates, which are related to the same Date table. As you are limited to one active relationship, we need to use the DAX function USERELATIONSHIP to manage the inactive relationships.  Link to Power BI file: https://curbal.com/blog/glossary/userelationship-dax

value.title: DAX Fridays! #23: ISFILTERED
value.excerpt: In this video we will through the ISFILTERED function in DAX.  This function is useful to detect when a column has been filtered and as shown in this video you can use it to set conditions when a column has been filtered. value.title: DAX Fridays! #26: Break RANKX ties with RAND()

value.title: DAX Fridays! #7: ALL, ALLEXCEPT
value.excerpt: The function ALL returns all the rows in a table, or all the values in a column, ignoring any filters that might have been applied. This function is useful for clearing filters and creating calculations on all the rows in a table.  The function ALLEXCEPT removes all filters except the ones that have
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/q4jePhzKtbU" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: DAX Fridays! #77: GROUPBY, CURRENTGROUP
value.excerpt: In today's DAX Fridays, we will go through the DAX function GROUPBY with an example.  GROUPBY is similar as SUMMARIZE, but the difference is that in the expression part, you use DAX iterators to get your results. You can also nest GROUPBY functions to get for example the highest sales amount by country.

value.excerpt: Have you got the following error when using the DAX function LOOKUPVALUES?  "A table of multiple values was supplied where a single value was expected"  in this video, I will show you why that error happens and what you need to do to resolve it and use the function as intended. value.title: DAX Fridays! #91: Sum child values into the parent
value.excerpt: In today's video, I will show you how to sum child values into the parent when you are dealing with hierarchies in Power BI.  This video is based on an example shown in the previous DAX Fridays! video, so I recommend you to watch that first: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e8OWQ7Xl3m0  Happy holidays!
